metadata.title: Base-free aerobic oxidation of 5-hydroxymethylfurfural to 2,5-furandicarboxylic acid in water by hydrotalcite-activated carbon composite supported gold catalyst

The HT/AC mass ratio was kept at 2:1. Reaction conditions: HMF, 0.5mmol; HMF/Au molar ratio, 100/1; H2O, 20mL; O2, 0.5MPa; temperature, 100°C; time, 12h. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 Time course for base-free aerobic oxidation of HMF over the 1%Au/HT-AC (2:1) catalyst. Reaction conditions: HMF, 0.5mmol; HMF/Au molar ratio, 100/1; H2O, 20mL; O2, 0.5MPa; temperature, 100°C. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 Base-free aerobic oxidation of HMF over the 1%Au/HT-AC (2:1) catalyst using O2 at different pressures. Reaction conditions: HMF, 0.5mmol; HMF/Au molar ratio, 100/1; H2O, 20mL; temperature, 100°C; time, 12h. Editor’s choice paper Base-free aerobic oxidation of 5-hydroxymethylfurfural to 2,5-furandicarboxylic acid in water by hydrotalcite-activated carbon composite supported gold catalyst Tianqi Gao Tianyu Gao Wenhao Fang ⁎ Qiue Cao School of Chemical Science and Technology, Key Laboratory of Medicinal Chemistry for Natural Resource – Ministry of Education, Yunnan University, 2 North Cuihu Road, 650091 Kunming, China School of Chemical Science and Technology Key Laboratory of Medicinal Chemistry for Natural Resource – Ministry of Education Yunnan University 2 North Cuihu Road Kunming 650091 China ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract Selective conversion of 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF) to 2,5-furandicarboxylic acid (FDCA) was studied using molecular oxygen without addition of any soluble base. A new, cheap and robust support (i.e. hydrotalcite-activated carbon composite, HT-AC) was prepared by physical milling of home-made HT and commercial AC, which required using less chemical consumption and simpler chemical protocol. Au/HT-AC catalyst showed superior catalytic performance for aerobic oxidation of HMF in water under mild conditions compared to Au/HT and Au/AC catalysts, respectively. It was found that the HT-AC support with the optimal ratio (2:1 in mass ratio) significantly enhanced FDCA yield and catalytic stability. After 12h at 100°C, 99.5% FDCA yield was achieved using O2 at 0.5MPa. Moreover, 99% FDCA yield was obtained using air as oxidant after 18h. The catalyst demonstrated remarkable stability during recycling up to six times. The influence of different reaction parameters was studied and optimized. Furthermore, the properties of catalysts were characterized by ICP-MS, N2 isotherms, XRD, XPS and TEM. Keywords Selective oxidation 5-hydroxyfurfural Base-free Gold nanoparticles Heterogeneous catalysis 1 Introduction The valorization of renewable lignocellulosic biomass for the sustainable production of fuels and chemicals has attracted much attention due to the depletion of fossil resources and environmental concerns. A very desirable approach is the (bio)chemical transformation of biomass to platform molecules followed by catalytic conversion into high-value-added chemicals, such as polymer precursors, pharmaceuticals and fine chemicals [1]. 5-Hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF) has been identified as a key and versatile platform compound derived from cellulosic C6 carbohydrates, because HMF can be used for the integrated production of various building-block compounds [2]. Particularly, 2,5-furandicarboxylic acid (FDCA), the symmetrical furanic diacid synthesized via oxidation of HMF, is a promising substitute for terephthalic acid that represents a petroleum-based monomer largely used for the manufacture of polyethylene terephthalate (PET) plastic [3]. Previously, stoichiometric oxidant like KMnO4 was used for HMF oxidation, leading to pollutants emission and toxicity issue [4]. Instead, using air as oxidant, homogenous Co/Mn/Br halides in the presence of corrosive solvent like acetic acid was employed, affording a moderate FDCA yield (ca. 60%) but under rather harsh reaction conditions (70bar) [5]. Obviously, homogeneous catalytic systems inevitably suffer from the problems of low atom efficiency, waste generation and catalyst recycling. In such a context, heterogeneous selective oxidation of HMF to FDCA using molecular oxygen is of great importance and has become a focus of oxidative model reactions for biorefineries [6,7]. Recent progress on the aerobic oxidation of HMF has been achieved by using supported noble metals. Representative active heterogeneous gold [8,9], palladium [10,11], platinum [12,13], and ruthenium [14,15] catalysts were reported. Nevertheless, the above-reported systems cannot work so well without the addition of 1–20 equivalent homogeneous bases (such as NaOH and K2CO3) in order to facilitate alkoxide formation and CH activation in the process. As a result, further acidification and purification are required for subsequent use of FDCA in the polymer industrial, hampering the green footprint of the process. Therefore, the aerobic oxidation of HMF to FDCA under base-free conditions is highly desirable but remains significant challenge. On the other hand, supported-Au nanoparticles have emerged as promising catalysts for diverse mild and efficient selective aerobic oxidations in liquid phase [16]. As Au-based catalysts can offer better resistance to water and oxygen, it is generally accepted that Au catalyst are more selective and stable for the aerobic oxidation of organic compounds in water rather than the conventional Pd and Pt oxidation catalysts. To the best of our knowledge, there is very few Au-based catalysts reported for the base-free aerobic oxidation of HMF, even if Pd [17], Pt [18,19] and Ru [20,21] catalysts have been developed. N.K. Gupta et al. showed that hydrotalcite-supported gold nanoparticle (Au/HT) catalyst can convert HMF to FDCA at 95°C without addition of homogeneous base. FDCA yield reached 99% and 81% using O2 or air at ambient pressure, respectively [22]. But it should be mentioned that during recycling FDCA yield decreased quickly to 90% after only two cycles due to the leaching of the basic sites of hydrotalcite in an aqueous solution. Following that, L. Ardemani et al. demonstrated that HT solid base could drive HMF oxidation but only in concert with very high concentrations of surface gold [23]. Apart from the monometallic Au catalysts, X. Wan et al. reported that carbon nanotube (CNT) supported Au-Pd alloy can afford high FDCA yield (>94%) at 100°C under 0.5MPa O2 while maintaining good stability [24]. However, CNT as support is rather expensive. It has to be also noted that CNT must be functionalized previously by HNO3 or H2O2 to enhance the adsorption of HMF and the intermediates, which is essential for realization of the base-free oxidation. Therefore, development of more cost-effective and stable heterogeneous Au catalyst is of still high importance and challenge. As it is known, Au catalyst may be deactivated more easily by the formed organic products like carboxylic acid in the absence of basic promoter. In light of this, developing inexpensive support materials that combine robust basic sites and sufficient adsorption of substrate/intermediates by using less chemical and facile protocol is becoming the breakthrough to Au catalyst for aerobic oxidation of HMF under base-free conditions. Herein we report for the first time a new and interesting support in the form of composite consisted of hydrotalcite and activated carbon (donated as HT-AC) that was prepared by a simple physical milling of two components. After immobilization of gold nanoparticles, the obtained Au/HT-AC catalyst is efficient and stable for base-free aerobic oxidation of HMF to FDCA in water under mild conditions. We will show the necessary use of HT-AC composite for the enhancement of FDCA yield and catalyst stability. We have investigated and optimized the different reaction parameters, such as reaction time, reaction temperature, and O2 pressure. And we have also studied the catalyst properties and the reusability. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials and reagents Mg(NO3)2·6H2O (>99%) and Al(NO3)3·9H2O (>98%) from Acros Organics, and (NH4)2CO3 and NH4OH from Sinopharm Chemical Co. Ltd. were used for synthesis of hydrotalcite (HT). Charcoal activated (AC) and polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP, >98%, MW=10,000) were purchased from Tokyo Chemical Industry Co. Ltd. HAuCl4·3H2O (49.0% on Au basis) and NaBH4 (>98%) were purchased from Alfa Aesar. 5-Hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF, 98%), 2,5-diformylfuran (DFF, 98%), 5-hydroxymethyl-2-furancarboxylic acid (HMFCA, 98%), 5-formylfuran-2-carboxylic acid (FFCA, 98%) and 2,5-furandicarboxylic acid (FDCA, 98%) from Ark Pharm were used for catalytic reactions and related quantification. All the chemicals were used as received without further purification or treatment. 2.2 Catalysts preparation Mg-Al HT was synthesized by an alkali-free co-precipitation method. To an aqueous solution of ammonium carbonate (1molL−1), an equivalent mixed solution of metal nitrates (1molL−1) with a molar ratio of Mg:Al=3:1 was slowly added under stirring at 600 rmp. The pH value of the mixture was adjusted to 8 by dropwise addition of 28wt% solution of ammonium hydroxide. The slurry was kept stirring at 65°C under condensation reflux for 18h. The resulting solids were recovered by filtration and washed by excessive deionized water when the filtrate presented a neutral pH value. The solids were afterwards oven-dried at 120°C for 12h followed by calcination at 500°C under an air flow for 4h. Although the crystalline structure of HT was lost during the calcining, it was regained after the subsequent process of catalyst preparation owing to the memory effect of HT (see Fig. S1 in supplementary material). HT-AC composites were prepared by manually milling the mixed powder of hydrotalcite and activated carbon. Typically, to an agate mortar (inner diameter: 110mm) 2g of HT and AC mixture with various mass ratios (HT:AC=3:1, 2:1, 1:1, 1:2, 1:3 and 1:4, respectively) was mixed and milled continuously and homogeneously at room temperature for 40min. The obtained black fine powder was oven-dried at 120°C for 1h. Au/HT-AC catalysts were prepared by immobilization of the PVP-stabilized colloidal Au nanoparticles onto the different HT-AC supports. In a typical protocol, a polyvinyl pyrrolidone (PVP, MW=10,000) aqueous solution was added into a HAuCl4 solution (PVP/HAuCl4 =1.2/1, in w/w) under stirring. A freshly made NaBH4 solution (NaBH4/HAuCl4 =5/1, in mol/mol) was slowly introduced into the mixture to yield a dark-purple colloidal solution. And then a suspension of powdery support was added and the mixture was vigorously stirred at room temperature for 2h. The solid catalyst was recovered by filtration and washed repeatedly with hot deionized water (95°C) to remove PVP and with excessive deionized water to remove Na+ and Cl− ions. Finally, the resultant Au/HT-AC catalyst was freeze-dried at −50°C for 24h. This protocol was also applicable to HT and AC as support, respectively. 2.3 Catalytic reaction The aerobic oxidation of HMF was performed in a batch-type Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave (50mL). Typically, HMF (0.5mmol) and catalyst (HMF/Au=100/1, in mol.) were added into the reactor with deionized H2O (20mL) as solvent. After the purge and introduction of O2 at a certain pressure (typically at 0.5MPa), the reactor was placed in an oil bath pre-heated at 100°C with magnetic stirring at 600rpm. After a fixed time (typically 12h unless otherwise specified), the reactor was quickly transferred to icy water. And then the spent catalyst was carefully separated by high-speed centrifugation (10,000rmp for 10min) and washed by ethanol three times followed by freeze-drying before its next use. The reactant and liquid products were analyzed on an Agilent 1260 Infinity high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) with a photodiode array detector (DAD) and a Shodex SH-1011 sugar column (8mm×300mm×6μm) using a dilute H2SO4 solution (5mM in water) as mobile phase. The quantification was carried out using the external standard method. Each product (DFF, HMFCA, FFCA and FDCA), as well as reactant (HMF), was calibrated by using its standard at different concentrations at the specific wavelength, i.e. 260nm for HMFCA and FDCA, 285nm for HMF, and 290nm for DFF and FFCA. The conversion of HMF and the selectivity of each product were defined as the molar percentage of HMF converted and the molar percentage of each product formed in HMF converted, respectively. Both the conversion and selectivity were calculated on a carbon basis. Each reaction was repeated twice at least to guarantee a reproducible result. 2.4 Catalyst characterizations The Au loading and Mg/Al ratio of HT were precisely analyzed by Inductively Coupled Plasma Mass Spectrometry (ICP-MS) technique using an Agilent 7500a apparatus. The textural properties were measured by N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms at 77K on a Quadrasorb evo ™ Surface Area and Pore Size Analyzer. The specific surface areas were calculated by the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method. Prior to the sorption measurements, the samples were degassed at 150°C for 3h. X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis was performed using a Rigaku TTR III Diffractometer provided with Cu Kα radiation (λ=1.5418Å) and a beam voltage of 40kV. The patterns were registered in the 2θ domain (5–90°) with a measured step of 0.02° and a time integration of 0.2s. The interlayer distance of HT containing materials was calculated by Bragg equation at the (003) plane. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis was carried out under ultra-high vacuum on a Thermo Scientific Escalab 250Xi system provided with Al Kα radiation. The binding energy shift due to the surface charging was adjusted using a reference to the C 1s line at 284.8eV. High resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) measurement was performed on a Philips-FEI TECNAI F30 field-emission electron microscope operated at an acceleration voltage of 300kV. Samples for TEM measurements were suspended in ethanol and dispersed ultrasonically. Drops of the suspension were applied on a lacey support film. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Influence of HT-AC mass ratio To disclose the effect of support composition, we started with two extreme catalysts, i.e. HT or AC supported 1wt% Au nanoparticles, respectively. As reported in Table 1 , Au/HT (Entry 1) provides 72% HMF conversion with 11% selectivity to FDCA at 100°C after 24h. The other products are HMFCA (66%) and FFCA (23%) that are oxidized intermediates from HMF (Scheme 1 ). On the other hand, Au/AC (Entry 2) provides rather low HMF conversion (4%) with no formation of FDCA. On this catalyst, DFF (19%, also recognized as oxidized intermediate from HMF) is produced in addition to HMFCA (64%) and FFCA (17%). This suggests that reactions over Au/HT or Au/AC catalyst may probably undergo different pathways. We have checked that the bare support, whatever HT (Entry 3) or AC (Entry 4) is almost unable to convert HMF with only trace formation of HMFCA and DFF, respectively. As expected, the HT-AC composite support (Entry 5) affords rather low HMF conversion, but with a small amount of FFCA in addition to HMFCA and DFF. To be noted, FDCA formation is not measured. This further confirms that Au/HT catalyst first oxidizes the aldehyde group in HMF to form HMFCA (Route I) [22], which has been also observed for HT supported Pd catalyst [17]. Whereas Au/AC catalyst oxidizes the hydroxyl group in HMF to form DFF (Route II) in addition to the former pathway (Route I), which is in agreement with the performance obtained on Au/CNT catalyst [24]. It seems that the HT-AC composite support could potentially facilitate oxidation of HMFCA and/or DFF to subsequent FFCA production. The HT-AC composite as catalyst support plays a crucial role in the base-free aerobic oxidation of HMF. Using HT-AC supported Au catalysts, HMF conversion reaches quickly over 93%, while FDCA selectivity varies between 25 and 99% that strongly depends on the HT-AC mass ratio (Entry 6–11). A volcano tendency can be well established between FDCA yield and HT-AC ratio. Total conversion of HMF and >99% selectivity to FDCA are obtained when HT-AC ratio is at 2:1. In such a case, only trace HMFCA is measured as by-product. Therefore, HT-AC composite is clearly superior to the sole HT or AC as support for selective oxidation of HMF to FDCA under base-free conditions. 3.2 Importance of HT-AC support in composite form In order to verify rigorously whether the HT-AC support in composite form being decisive for realization of the high performance of oxidation, we carried out a comparison study on two referenced catalysts (i.e. 1%Au/HT and 1%Au/AC) with the optimal 1%Au/HT-AC (2:1) catalyst. In such a case, additional AC or HT was added to 1%Au/HT and 1%Au/AC catalysts, respectively, during the reaction. It has to be mentioned that HT/AC mass ratio was kept at 2:1 for all the catalysts investigated. Moreover, reaction time was shortened to 12h in order to see the possible differences, as the activity of the 1%Au/HT-AC (2:1) catalyst was already saturated after reaction for 24h. As reported in Fig. 1 , 1%Au/HT-AC (2:1) demonstrates 100% conversion of HMF and >99% selectivity to FDCA, showing rather high activity under mild conditions. As expected, the referenced 1%Au/HT+AC catalyst affords much lower FDCA selectivity (ca. 63%) even if HMF is completely converted. Whereas the other referenced 1%Au/AC+HT catalyst provides only 39% conversion and rather low FDCA selectivity (ca. 4%). In fact, these results are already ameliorated largely as compared to those obtained over Au/HT or Au/AC catalyst in terms of HMF conversion and FDCA yield (Table 2 ). Thus the co-presence of HT and AC in the support would promote formation of FDCA. However, as differences can be seen that addition of AC to Au/HT catalyst apparently increases FDCA yield while addition of HT to Au/AC catalyst mainly promotes the conversion of HMF to oxidized intermediates rather than FDCA. To be noted, quantitative FDCA yield can be only obtained on HT-AC composite supported Au catalyst. Furthermore, the developed Au/HT-AC catalyst towards HMF conversion and FDCA yield under base-free conditions was compared with recently reported hydrotalcite or carbon materials supported Au catalysts (Table 2). It can be seen that Au/C and Au/CNT catalysts (Entry 8 and 9) afford rather low yield (1%) to FDCA [22,24], in consistent with our result obtained on Au/AC catalyst (Entry 5). While Au/HT catalysts (Entry 4, 6 and 7) from different works demonstrate FDCA yield at between 8% and 99% depending on different reaction conditions [22,23]. However, it must be pointed out that Au/HT catalyst reported by N.K. Gupta et al. apparently suffered from instability during recycling even if 99% yield to FDCA was achieved at the first reaction cycle. On the contrary, the developed Au/HT-AC catalyst shows not only 99% yield to FDCA but also very high catalytic stability, which is one of the best in the literature as a competitive and efficient heterogeneous catalyst for base-free conversion of HMF to FDCA. Therefore, the combinative use of HT and AC in composite form as support is very essential to achieve high conversion of HMF in the absence of homogenous bases. Moreover, HT-AC support in composite form is found prerequisite for the enhancement of selectivity to FDCA. It thus can be predicted that such HT-AC composites enable to share the features of HT and AC with synergy between two components. Hence, only physical milling with adequate time and strength such as the conditions employed in this work allows obtaining the desirable HT-AC composite support. 3.3 Influence of reaction time The studies on time course for the conversion of HMF may provide information on the reaction pathways and mechanism. In light of this, we monitored HMF conversion and product selectivities over the 1%Au/HT-AC (2:1) catalyst as a function of reaction time. The data was obtained by one reading per experiment for each reaction time. As plotted in Fig. 2 , HMF conversion and FDCA selectivity undergo a global increase. Conversion approaches to 100% after only 4h of reaction and achieves complete after 6h. Selectivity to HMFCA increases quickly up to 72% with reaction time in the initial 1h and starts to decrease regularly as the reaction time exceeds. Selectivity to FFCA follows a very similar evolution but in a much lower decreasing trend. On the other hand, selectivity to FDCA increases almost monotonically with reaction time and achieves 99.5% after 12h, remaining only trace HMFCA (0.4%) and FFCA (0.1%) production. These observations clearly indicate a tandem reaction pathway for the conversion of HMF to FDCA via HMFCA and FFCA over Au/HT-AC catalyst (Scheme 1, Route I), which is well consistent with the previous studies using oxides supported Au catalysts, such as Au/TiO2, Au/CeO2 and Au/HT [22,25,26]. For FDCA production from HMF, it is necessary to simultaneously oxidize both the aldehyde and the hydroxyl groups in HMF. In the present work, the conversion of aldehyde group of HMF into carboxyl group of HMFCA (Scheme 1, step 1) is occurred very quickly even during the initial 1h, which can be interpreted by the formation of the intermediate hemiacetal due to the basic supports, such as hydrotalcite [26]. And then the subsequent oxidation of hydroxyl group of HMFCA to aldehyde group of FFCA (step 2) is found much slower, which requires the catalytic bifunction of active metal species and basic sites of support [22]. This step has been usually considered as the rate-determining step for the overall reaction. Finally FFCA is rapidly converted into FDCA (step 3) following the same process of step 1. This body of results shows that HMF oxidation over Au/HT-AC catalyst undergoes the same pathway as that of Au/HT catalyst rather than that of Au/AC catalyst. This proposed reaction pathway over Au/HT-AC catalyst can be also supported by the results of the influence of O2 pressure. 3.4 Influence of reaction temperature Table 3 reported the influence of reaction temperature on the aerobic oxidation of HMF. It can be seen that both conversion of HMF and selectivity to products are sensitive to the temperature used for the oxidation. Generally, the higher reaction temperature is used, the higher FDCA yield is obtained. When the oxidation is performed at 80°C, the conversion of HMF reaches 78%. As temperature increases to 90°C, conversion is almost complete. Further increase in temperature leads to higher selectivity to FDCA while conversion maintains complete. During the investigated temperature domain, oxidative intermediates including HMFCA and FFCA are largely converted to FDCA with increasing temperature. Hence, higher reaction temperature promotes conversion of HMF to FDCA. However, one should mention that small amount of byproducts are observed in reaction at 110°C, but those are difficult in being identified. 3.5 Influence of O2 pressure and air as oxidant Fig. 3 showed the dependence of conversion of HMF and selectivity of products on O2 pressures in the reactor between 0.1 and 0.5MPa. HMF conversion maintains complete toward the O2 pressures investigated, while FDCA selectivity increases gradually with higher O2 pressure. It has to be emphasized that a good result, i.e. 83% selectivity to FDCA at 100% conversion of HMF, can be already obtained at the ambient O2 pressure (0.1MPa) under very mild conditions. It can be assumed that FDCA selectivity may be probably promoted by adjusting other parameters like by simple extension of reaction time. At lower pressures (≤0.4MPa), HMFCA and FFCA as the intermediate products are formed, suggesting that the oxidation process is incomplete. The oxidation of HMFCA to FFCA is observed slowly with increasing O2 pressure, which well matches with the previous interpretation of reaction pathway. The use of O2 at 0.5MPa is necessary to achieve the quantitative selectivity (>99%) to FDCA under the given conditions. As a matter of fact, such a condition is found still competitive as compared to some existing base-free systems [19,20]. Using air as oxidant is even more cost-effective than oxygen and is of importance for the industrial application. For this purpose, we continued to investigate the capability of the 1%Au/HT-AC (2:1) catalyst toward selective conversion of HMF under air in base-free conditions. The time course for HMF oxidation, as plotted in Fig. S2, follows the similar tendency of that obtained under O2 especially during the initial 6h. HMF reaches full conversion with FDCA selectivity at ca. 58% after 6h. But it can be clearly seen that during the whole duration the conversion of HMF and HMFCA appears less fast by using air as oxidant instead of O2. In such a case, high FDCA selectivity at 99% is obtained after longer reaction time for 18h. Therefore, quantitative yield to FDCA can be achieved using air as oxidant by simple extension of reaction time. 3.6 Influence of Au loading Metal loading in supported catalysts is of general interest. For this reason, we compared the catalytic behaviors of Au/HT-AC (2:1) catalysts with different Au loadings at the initial 1h of reaction, because quantitative yield to FDCA was obtained after 12h. As reported in Table 4 , the optimal result is obtained over the catalyst with the lowest Au loading at 1%. Conversion of HMF and selectivity to FDCA are apparently decreased with an increase in Au loading. As the mass of catalyst used is on the basis of Au molar fraction to HMF, and moreover the precise Au loadings measured by ICP-MS are very close to the theoretical values, it thus can be primarily speculated that Au loading would influence the intrinsic activity of Au/HT-AC catalysts probably in different ways, such as dispersion of Au particles on surface, distribution of Au particle sizes, and etc. As it is known to all, different Au loadings may be expected to form different morphologies and different particles sizes. It is of interest to be verified by further studies in depth in the point view of structure-activity correlation. 3.7 Studies on catalyst recycling The stability and reusability of heterogeneous catalysts are of great importance for any potential application and prospect of industrialization. For this reason, we performed studies for the 1%Au/HT-AC (2:1) catalyst on a series of consecutive tests performed at 100°C for 12h in the absence of homogeneous base. After each test, the catalyst was simply recovered by the high-speed centrifugation, washing in ethanol and water to remove the reactant and products retained by the solid and freeze-drying before its next use. The 1%Au/HT-AC (2:1) catalyst shows an excellent stability after six consecutive cycles (Fig. 4 ). HMF conversion maintains higher than 99% in all runs and FDCA selectivity remains considerable stable at ca. 98% with little decrease. This result is one of the best among the reported Au catalysts for HMF oxidation under base-free conditions [22–24]. FDCA yield with especially the catalytic stability has been enhanced using a cheap and stable material supported monometallic Au catalyst. Compared to Pt, Pd and Ru systems, Au/HT-AC catalyst is also competitive since quantitative FDCA yield is achieved using relatively lower temperature, O2 pressure and catalyst amount (metal/HMF molar ratio). 4 Characterizations of catalysts 4.1 Bulk composition, textural properties and crystalline phases To understand the interesting catalytic performances, we carried out primary characterizations on some typical catalysts. We first analyzed the Au loadings of different samples by Inductively Coupled Plasma Mass Spectrometry (ICP-MS). As listed in Table 5 , all the measured Au loadings in weight percentage respect very well to the theoretical values, showing that almost all of the colloidal Au nanoparticles can be effectively immobilized onto HT, AC and HT-AC supports using the given protocol. The Mg/Al atomic ratio in HT is measured at 2.91, in consistent with the ratio of the starting materials. N2 adsorption-desorption measurement provided the textural properties of catalysts. Au/HT (Entry 1, Table 5) exhibits the lowest specific surface area at 204m2 g−1, while Au/AC (Entry 5) exhibits the largest value at 1594m2 g−1 due to the high specific surface area of the activated carbon used as support. Au/HT-AC catalysts (Entry 2–4) with the different support compositions show moderate specific surface areas (390–1207m2 g−1) and the values appear in proportion to the HT/AC mass ratio. Particularly, the 1%Au/HT-AC (2:1) catalyst exhibits a value at about 550m2 g−1. It is generally believed that support material with large specific surface area is important for high dispersion of surface active species like gold nanoparticles. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis allowed phase and crystalline structures to be identified. From Fig. S3 it can be seen that Au/HT catalyst displays the characteristic diffraction peaks due to the double layered hydrotalcite compound for (003), (006), (012), (015), (018), (110) and (113) planes, according to 70–2151 JCPDS index; and Au/AC catalyst presents two broad bands at about 20–30° and 40–50° attributed to the amorphous graphitic carbon for (002) and (100) plane [27]. The XRD patterns of Au/HT-AC catalysts appear similar to that of hydrotalcite, and the intensity and crystallinity alter depending on the HT/AC ratio. Au/HT-AC (3:1 and 2:1) samples with higher HT proportion demonstrate well-crystallized structures related to HT phase and no obvious other crystalline phases are observed. But when HT/AC ratio decreases to 1:3, the patterns become clearly less intense and less crystallized than HT, which is proved by the shape modification of the diffraction peaks, showing the pronounced influence of activated carbon structure on HT-AC composite. Further calculation of the interlayer distances of HT presented in the catalysts from the most intense (003) plane shows a slight increase compared to the value of Mg/Al HT compound. This phenomenon indicates that amorphous AC may be probably incorporated well into HT structure, which leads to hybrid material comprising both functions from HT and AC. Moreover, no diffraction lines attributed to Au species is detected for any studied catalyst probably due to the very low Au loading and/or small Au participle sizes beyond the detection limit. 4.2 Surface features and microstructure To collect more information on the Au nanoparticles, we carried out surface examinations for the typical catalysts by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). All the studied catalysts present binding energies (BEs) for Au 4f7/2 at 83.5–84.3eV (as listed in Table 4), which has been largely assigned to the typical metallic gold (Au0) species [24,28]. Fig. 5 reports the Au 4f XPS spectrum for the representative 1%Au/HT-AC (2:1) catalyst. The plotted Au 4f7/2 band centered at 84.3eV matches very well to that of Au0 species. The Au 4f5/2 band is overlapped by the Mg 2s XPS peak located at ca. 85–90eV. We have also examined the C 1s and O 1s regions to reveal the possible role that AC plays in the catalyst. A typical asymmetric C 1s band and a typical symmetric O 1s band are observed. Further deconvolution of C 1s spectrum leads to four peaks that can be attributed to the carbon species in CC (284.8eV) of graphite, CO (286.2eV) of phenolic, hydroxyl or ether groups, CO (287.3eV) of carbonyl or quinone groups, and COO (289.5eV) of carboxyl group, respectively [19,27]. On the other hand, deconvolution of O 1s region yields four peaks that can be assigned to carbonyl oxygen of quinones (531.8eV), oxygen atoms in hydroxyl groups (532.7eV), non-carbonyl (ether-type) oxygen atoms (533.5eV), and oxygen atoms in carboxyl groups (534.4eV), respectively [29]. XPS analysis of C 1s and O 1s bands is well consistent. Thereby the employed AC is found well decorated by surface O-containing functional groups. Of those hydroxyl, carbonyl and quinone groups bonding to carbon nanotube has been disclosed very important to facilitate the adsorption of HMF and the intermediates and thus accelerate the formation of FDCA [18,24]. Therefore, the activated carbon presented in HT-AC support, which bears surface hydroxyl and carbonyl/quinone groups, could probably be able to promote the formation of FDCA, in addition to the function of the basic sites of hydrotalcite. We further studied the microstructure of HT-AC support and Au morphology of the 1%Au/HT-AC (2:1) catalyst by transmission electron microscopy (TEM). Typical thin layered structure of HT is clearly observed from TEM images shown in Fig. 6 a, b. In the meantime, the amorphous carbon (AC) is also clearly found in overlap to HT, which is in good agreement with XRD observation. Moreover, uniform Au nanoparticles in small sizes are observed highly dispersed on the surface of HT-AC support. The Au particle size is in narrow distribution with an average value at 2.5±0.5nm (Fig. 6d). HRTEM image shows the morphology for the representative Au nanoparticle (Fig. 6c). Most often, this accumulation modelling is used for the description of geometric morphology for unsupported or supported Au nanoclusters [30]. When gold atoms are accumulated in a truncated cubo-octahedral geometry, the exposed lower-coordination-number atoms, that is, edge and corner gold atoms are generally believed to be highly active in catalysis [31]. As a matter of fact, such small Au nanoparticles (mean particle size at ca. 2nm) presenting this morphology loaded on HT have been found very efficient for the base-free aerobic oxidation or the oxidant-free dehydrogenation of liquid alcohols in our previous work [32]. In addition to that, Au/HT-AC (2:1) catalysts with different Au loadings were also analyzed by TEM as reported in Fig. S4. It can be seen that the mean size of Au nanoparticles, especially the proportion of bigger particles obviously grows with increasing Au loading. Hence, the morphology of Au nanoparticles that depends on the particle size would probably affect the catalytic activity. It is worthy of doing further studies in depth to better understand the correlation between the morphology of nano-catalysts and their catalytic activity. In short, unique HT-AC support in concert with highly active Au nanoparticles in small sizes is responsible for the enhanced performance of Au/HT-AC catalyst for base-free HMF oxidation. 4.3 Analysis of the used 1%Au/HT-AC (2:1) catalyst To verify the stability of the catalyst during the reaction, we further characterized the spent 1%Au/HT-AC (2:1) catalyst after the complete repeated uses. Before analysis, the solid was washed with ethanol and water respectively and freeze-dried. XPS spectrum confirms no obvious change of the chemical state of Au nanoparticles (Fig. S5). The BE of Au 4f7/2 at 84.2eV is assigned to typical Au0 species, indicating resistance of Au species to the present reaction conditions. TEM image shows that the characteristic structures of HT and AC in overlapping are well maintained. Moreover, the particle size and distribution of Au are found very close to those of the fresh catalyst (Fig. S5), showing no obvious aggregation of Au particles during the oxidation process. ICP-MS analysis of the reaction mixture shows trace concentration of Au, probably due to the very slight leaching of Au species from catalyst. It can be assumed that the very minor deactivation of activity may be due to that. However, it has to be mentioned that the possible loss of the catalyst mass during the centrifugation steps can be also associated with the variation of stability. It is worth noting that the developed HT-AC support is found very resistant to the loss of the basic sites (leaching of Mg species into an aqueous solution) of HT that is often observed in the organic reaction environment [17,22]. Therefore, the Au/HT-AC catalyst demonstrates superior stability and reusability for the selective aerobic oxidation of HMF in base-free conditions. 5 Conclusions In this work, we have shown that gold nanoparticles loaded on hydrotalcite-activated carbon composites (HT-AC) is an efficient and stable heterogeneous catalyst for the aerobic oxidation of 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF) into 2,5-furandicarboxylic acid (FDCA) in water under base-free conditions. The low-cost HT-AC composite is prepared by simple physical milling of the two components at room temperature. The so-obtained HT-AC supports exhibit large surface area, basic sites, and surface hydroxyl and carbonyl groups, being very ideal for high dispersion of Au nanoparticles and adsorption of HMF as well as intermediates. The immobilized Au nanoparticles are found small and uniform in size which resist aggregation and deactivation to the oxidation conditions. It has been disclosed that the HT-AC mass ratio in the composite form and the metallic gold particles in small sizes play a crucial role in determining FDCA yield. The Au/HT-AC catalyst is efficient in converting HMF to FDCA and oxidation of HMFCA to FFCA is considered as the rate-determining step for the overall reaction. Using molecular oxygen or air as oxidant under mild conditions (HMF/Au=100/1 in mol/mol, 100°C, 0.5MPa), the catalyst demonstrates superior yield to FDCA and reusability. coredata.dc:description: Selective conversion of 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF) to 2,5-furandicarboxylic acid (FDCA) was studied using molecular oxygen without addition of any soluble base. A new, cheap and robust support (i.e. hydrotalcite-activated carbon composite, HT-AC) was prepared by physical milling of home-made HT and commercial AC, which required using less chemical consumption and simpler chemical protocol. Au/HT-AC catalyst showed superior catalytic performance for aerobic oxidation of HMF in water under mild conditions compared to Au/HT and Au/AC catalysts, respectively. It was found that the HT-AC support with the optimal ratio (2:1 in mass ratio) significantly enhanced FDCA yield and catalytic stability. After 12h at 100°C, 99.5% FDCA yield was achieved using O2 at 0.5MPa. Moreover, 99% FDCA yield was obtained using air as oxidant after 18h. The catalyst demonstrated remarkable stability during recycling up to six times. The influence of different reaction parameters was studied and optimized. Furthermore, the properties of catalysts were characterized by ICP-MS, N2 isotherms, XRD, XPS and TEM.
coredata.dc:title: Base-free aerobic oxidation of 5-hydroxymethylfurfural to 2,5-furandicarboxylic acid in water by hydrotalcite-activated carbon composite supported gold catalyst
